title: Mountain Pose (Tadasana)
description: Mountain Pose is the foundation of all standing poses. It improves posture, strengthens the legs, and helps with focus.
instructions: Stand straight with feet together or slightly apart.
Distribute weight evenly across both feet.
Engage your knees, draw in your thighs, and contract your glutes.
Lower your shoulders, let your arms hang naturally with palms facing thighs.
Lengthen your neck, gaze forward.
Breathe calmly for 30–60 seconds.

title: Mindfulness Meditation
description: A practice of being present in the moment without judging thoughts or feelings. Ideal for reducing anxiety.
instructions: Sit comfortably on a chair, cushion, or bench.
Keep your back straight but not tense.
Close your eyes or lower your gaze.
Focus on your breath: inhale and exhale.
When thoughts distract you, gently return to your breath.
Practice for 5–10 minutes daily.

title: Downward-Facing Dog (Adho Mukha Svanasana)
description: One of the most common poses, it stretches the entire body, particularly the back, legs, and shoulders.
instructions: Start in a tabletop position on all fours.
Place your hands slightly ahead of your shoulders, fingers spread wide.
Lift your hips up, straightening your legs (knees can be slightly bent).
Form an inverted triangle with your body from shoulders to heels.
Keep your head between your arms, neck relaxed.
Breathe deeply for 30–60 seconds.

title: Pranayama Breathing: Nadi Shodhana
description: Alternate nostril breathing calms the mind and balances energy flows.
benefits: Balances left and right brain hemispheres
instructions: Sit upright with a straight spine.
Using your right hand, form a 'mudra gesture': thumb and ring finger free.
Close your right nostril with your thumb.
Inhale slowly through your left nostril.
Close your left nostril with your ring finger, open your right, and exhale.
Inhale through the right, close it, exhale through the left—this is one cycle.
Repeat for 5–10 cycles.

title: Child’s Pose (Balasana)
description: A relaxing pose for rest and recovery, excellent for relieving back tension.
instructions: Kneel with your hips resting on your heels.
Lean forward, placing your chest between your thighs.
Extend your arms forward or rest them alongside your body, palms up.
Rest your forehead on the floor.
Breathe calmly for 1–3 minutes.

title: Body Scan Meditation
description: A meditation practice where you sequentially focus on each part of the body, from toes to head.
instructions: Lie on your back with arms at your sides, palms up.
Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths.
Focus on the tips of your toes, feeling them.
Slowly move upward: feet, ankles, calves, knees, thighs...
Continue to the crown of your head.
Stay in this state for 5–10 minutes.
Slowly return to awareness.

title: Warrior II Pose (Virabhadrasana II)
description: A classic power pose that builds endurance and concentration.
instructions: Stand straight, take a wide step back.
Bend your front knee to a 90-degree angle, keep the back leg straight.
Extend your arms parallel to the floor.
Gaze forward.
Hold the pose for 30–60 seconds on each side.

title: Tree Pose (Vrksasana)
description: A balancing pose that develops stability and focus.
instructions: Stand straight with feet together.
Place the sole of your right foot on the inner thigh of your left leg.
Press your palms together at chest level or raise your arms overhead.
Maintain balance and steady breathing.
Hold for 30–60 seconds, then switch legs.

title: Corpse Pose (Savasana)
description: A final relaxation pose to restore energy.
instructions: Lie on your back with arms and legs relaxed.
Close your eyes.
Focus on your breath.
Fully release tension.
Remain for 5–10 minutes.

title: Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana)
description: A gentle backbend that strengthens the spine and opens the chest.
instructions: Lie face down with palms under your shoulders.
On an inhale, lift your chest, straightening your arms.
Draw your shoulders back and down.
Keep your hips and legs pressed into the floor.
Breathe calmly for 15–30 seconds.
